organization.$: Department of Macromolecular Science and Engineering

head.citation-title: Polybenzoxazine-based composites for increased dielectric constant
head.abstracts: Polybenzoxazines show promising mechanical, thermal, and electrical properties for the fabrication of new materials for embedded capacitors or printed circuit board applications. They are a new class of thermosetting polymers being developed as an alternative to the traditional phenolics, epoxies, bismaleimides, and polyimides. They also provide features that are not found in the conventional materials, such as excellent dimensional stability, low water absorption, high char yield, good electrical properties, and wide molecular design flexibility. Moreover, polybenzoxazines can polymerize without the addition of strong acid or alkaline catalysts, and no byproducts are generated during the polymerization. This chapter states that the main material properties in capacitor applications are dielectric constant and dissipation factor or dielectric loss at specific temperature and frequency. Driven by current market needs, smaller devices are preferred, which results in the continuous development of materials with higher dielectric constants. Dielectric constants of polybenzoxazine as reported by various studies are influenced by the molecular structure of benzoxazine monomers. The dielectric properties of the polybenzoxazine composites are influenced by many factors such as the molecular structure of the benzoxazine, ceramic volume fraction, the distribution of ceramic powders, and the types of connectivities between ceramic fillers. Ceramics with a perovskite structure such as lead zirconate titanate (PZT), barium titanate (BaTiO3), and BST (Ba:Sr)TiO3 are mostly selected as dielectric boosters. However, it is necessary to ensure the proper surface modification of ceramic filler in polybenzoxazine composites; this not only increases the dielectric constant dramatically but also improves the distribution and lowers the dielectric loss of the polybenzoxazine composite. © 2011 Copyright © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
